balanced accuracy: Accuracy of model .More the scores better the model is
statistical parity difference: The ideal value of this metric is  0 . A value < 0 implies higher benefit for the privileged group and a value >0 implies a higher benefit for the unprivileged group
disparate impact ratio: The ideal value of this metric is 1.0 A value < 1 implies higher benefit for the privileged group and a value >1 implies a higher benefit for the unprivileged group
average odds difference: The ideal value of this metric is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the unprivileged group
equal opportunity difference: The ideal value of this metric is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the unprivileged group
theil index: A value of 0 implies perfect fairness. Fairness is indicated by lower scores, higher scores are problematic
true positive rate difference: The ideal value is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the unprivileged group.
false posiitve rate difference: The ideal value is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group.
false negative rate difference: The ideal value is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group.
false omission rate difference: The ideal value is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group.
false discovery rate difference: The ideal value is 0. A value of < 0 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 0 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group
false posiitve rate ratio: The ideal value is 1 . A value of < 1 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 1 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group.
false negative rate ratio: The ideal value is 1. A value of < 1 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 1 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group.
false omission rate ratio: The ideal value is 1. A value of < 1 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 1 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group
false discovery rate ratio: The ideal value is 1 . A value of < 1 implies higher benefit for the Un-privileged group and a value > 1 implies higher benefit for the Privileged group
accuracy: Accuracy of model. More the scores better the model
error rate: 1- accuracy. Lower the scores better the model
number of true positives: Number of data points which are actually postive and predicted as positive
number of false positives: Number of data points which are actually Negative but predicted as positive
number of false negatives: Number of data points which are actually Positive but predicted as Negative
number of true negatives: Number of data points which are actually Negative and also predicted as  negative
true positive rate: Out of all positives how many predicted as postive
false posiitve rate: Out of all negative points how many points are falsly predicted as positive
false negative rate: Out of all positive points how many are falsly predicted as negative (Ratio of False negatives over all the positive points in dataset )
true negative rate: Out of all negative points how many are truely predicted as negative
precision: More the scores better the model
recall: More the scores better the model
sensitivity: More the scores better the model
specificity: More the scores better the model
false omission rate: Out of all predicted Negative points how many of them are actually predicted as false. Near to zero is better
false discovery rate: Out of all predicted positive points how many of them are actually predicted as false. Lower the score better the model
adjusted mutual info score: Adjusted Mutual Information (AMI) is an adjustment of the Mutual Information (MI) score to account for chance. It accounts for the fact that the MI is generally higher for two clusterings with a larger number of clusters. The strength of proxy is given by this score. We wish to measure how strongly a random feature X is a proxy for protected feature Z
normalized mutual info score: Normalized Mutual Information (NMI) is a normalization of the Mutual Information (MI) score to scale the results between 0 (no mutual information) and 1 (perfect correlation). The strength of proxy is given by this score. We wish to measure how strongly a random feature X is a proxy for protected feature Z.
Fairness: More the score Fairer the model.
